title: URL link spoofing

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
Words such as `http://example.com` and `example.com` included in the message are displayed by URL link. This URL link naturally links to `example.com`. However, we can spoof the link destination by changing the message post request.

```diff
 POST /api/chat.postMessage HTTP/1.1
 Host: example.slack.com
 ...

 ...
 -----------------------------87462859699239992111770463
 Content-Disposition: form-data; name="text"

-http://example.com
+<http://evil.com|http://example.com>
 -----------------------------87462859699239992111770463
 ...
```

The URL link `http://example.com` is displayed in the message, but in fact it is linked to `evil.com`. For example, like [http://example.com](http://evil.com).

{F408013}

I took a screenshot of Slack on Chrome, so the link destination is displayed in the status bar. However, desktop apps and mobile apps do not have a status bar.

## Impact

It is used for phishing attack. For example, an attacker posts a message like the following. Victims click on this URL link will lead to a fake login page.

{F408014}

In addition, [It is already known](https://twitter.com/buritica/status/970721576034455552) that we can create Slack accounts with the same name. Therefore, an attacker can increase the success rate of phishing by spoofing an influential person.

{F408015}
vulnerability_information_html:
Words such as http://example.com and example.com included in the message are displayed by URL link. This URL link naturally links to example.com. However, we can spoof the link destination by changing the message post request.

 POST /api/chat.postMessage HTTP/1.1
 Host: example.slack.com
 ...

 ...
 -----------------------------87462859699239992111770463
 Content-Disposition: form-data; name="text"

-http://example.com
+<http://evil.com|http://example.com>
 -----------------------------87462859699239992111770463
 ...

The URL link http://example.com is displayed in the message, but in fact it is linked to evil.com. For example, like http://example.com.

I took a screenshot of Slack on Chrome, so the link destination is displayed in the status bar. However, desktop apps and mobile apps do not have a status bar.

Impact

It is used for phishing attack. For example, an attacker posts a message like the following. Victims click on this URL link will lead to a fake login page.

In addition, It is already known that we can create Slack accounts with the same name. Therefore, an attacker can increase the success rate of phishing by spoofing an influential person.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

While we are able to reproduce this behavior, this attack is predicated on a "team member against team member" attack scenario. We generally consider teams to be somewhat "Trusted spaces", and as such, we generally require a higher severity bar for vulnerabilities that exist only within a team. For this reason, we will not be making a change here and will be closing this report as "Informative".

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

While we are able to reproduce this behavior, this attack is predicated on a "team member against team member" attack scenario. We generally consider teams to be somewhat "Trusted spaces", and as such, we generally require a higher severity bar for vulnerabilities that exist only within a team. For this reason, we will not be making a change here and will be closing this report as "Informative".

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message: Hi @bugtriage-josh, thank you for your explanations. I was able to understand your policy.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @bugtriage-josh, thank you for your explanations. I was able to understand your policy.

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

I recently read the following article and learned that Slack can work with Outlook.
https://slackhq.com/increase-everyday-productivity-with-office-365-apps-for-slack

If the victim has forwarded the email received in Outlook to Slack, the attacker can post a fake URL link from outside the team to Slack by sending an email to the victim. This attack is different from the "team member against team member" attack scenario.

If you expect Slack to act as an email in the future, I recommend fixing this vulnerability. Do you plan to reopen this report and review its severity?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

I recently read the following article and learned that Slack can work with Outlook.
https://slackhq.com/increase-everyday-productivity-with-office-365-apps-for-slack

If the victim has forwarded the email received in Outlook to Slack, the attacker can post a fake URL link from outside the team to Slack by sending an email to the victim. This attack is different from the "team member against team member" attack scenario.

If you expect Slack to act as an email in the future, I recommend fixing this vulnerability. Do you plan to reopen this report and review its severity?

activities.message:
Thank you for your followup @akaki

We have recently instituted a "reward-on-triage" policy for many of our reports.  This issue is still open and we are still working on it, but we wanted to offer some compensation to you now as it's been a little while since originally reported.  Once the issue is fixed, we will ask you to verify the fix from your end and then mark the issue as "Resolved"

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh 

I verified that the vulnerability I reported last year was fixed. However, I can still spoof a URL link by using newline characters. I recommend that you also fix this vulnerability for safety.

```diff
 -----------------------------7333129693824198502059347126
 Content-Disposition: form-data; name="blocks"
 
-[{"type":"rich_text","elements":[{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"link","url":"https://example.com"}]}]}]
+[{"type":"rich_text","elements":[{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"link","url":"https://example.com\n\n\n\n\n@evil.com"}]}]}]
 -----------------------------7333129693824198502059347126
```
{F715440}

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

When accessing the URL with embedded userinfo from old Firefox, a warning dialog is displayed, but it is not displayed in the latest Firefox 73. Moreover, Chrome ignores userinfo. The following screenshot was taken on the latest Chrome 80.

{F718017}

In addition, I was able to access `evil.com` from the Slack apps for macOS, iOS and Android. IE and Edge no longer support userinfo, so if you set other browsers as default, you can also access them from the Slack app for Windows.

Please consider whether you need to fix such URL link spoofing as well.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

When accessing the URL with embedded userinfo from old Firefox, a warning dialog is displayed, but it is not displayed in the latest Firefox 73. Moreover, Chrome ignores userinfo. The following screenshot was taken on the latest Chrome 80.

In addition, I was able to access evil.com from the Slack apps for macOS, iOS and Android. IE and Edge no longer support userinfo, so if you set other browsers as default, you can also access them from the Slack app for Windows.

Please consider whether you need to fix such URL link spoofing as well.

activities.message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

You've updated to allow posting hyperlink, didn't you?
https://twitter.com/SlackHQ/status/1230587660948762624

In addition, have you updated the UI to display the correct URL in the popup? I tried to spoof the URL link using newline characters in another space where hyperlinks can be posted, but I couldn't spoof it in the popup.
{F725065}

I've also seen a confirm dialog displayed for simply spoofed URL link.
{F725067}

I hope this wonderful update will be rolled out to all spaces.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh,

You've updated to allow posting hyperlink, didn't you?
https://twitter.com/SlackHQ/status/1230587660948762624

In addition, have you updated the UI to display the correct URL in the popup? I tried to spoof the URL link using newline characters in another space where hyperlinks can be posted, but I couldn't spoof it in the popup.

I've also seen a confirm dialog displayed for simply spoofed URL link.

I hope this wonderful update will be rolled out to all spaces.

activities.message:
Hey @akaki,

Yes, this warning dialog is actually part of the Hyperlink text feature that has been in the works.  It's actually not in all workspaces yet, but should be soon. It's noted in our documentation here:

https://slack.com/help/articles/202288908-Format-your-messages-Format-your-messages
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @akaki,

Yes, this warning dialog is actually part of the Hyperlink text feature that has been in the works. It's actually not in all workspaces yet, but should be soon. It's noted in our documentation here:

https://slack.com/help/articles/202288908-Format-your-messages-Format-your-messages

activities.message:
Hey @bugtriage-josh,

Thank you for sharing the detailed article. I also have one thing I'd like to share with you. I said on Feb 13th that "I verified that the vulnerability I reported last year was fixed," but now I can reproduce it.

```diff
 -----------------------------794120736176343847283603669
-Content-Disposition: form-data; name="blocks"
+Content-Disposition: form-data; name="text"
 
-[{"type":"rich_text","elements":[{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"link","url":"https://evil.com","text":"https://example.com"}]}]}]
+<https://evil.com|https://example.com>
 -----------------------------794120736176343847283603669
```

However, now that the popup and warning dialog appear, I think the impact of this vulnerability has been sufficiently mitigated. You may already know that, but just in case.

-[{"type":"rich_text","elements":[{"type":"rich_text_section","elements":[{"type":"link","url":"https://evil.com","text":"https://example.com"}]}]}]

However, now that the popup and warning dialog appear, I think the impact of this vulnerability has been sufficiently mitigated. You may already know that, but just in case.

activities.message:
Hey @bugtriage-josh,

This report is currently scheduled to be disclosed at March 21. Your warning dialog works on Slack for Android app v20.03.20 but not on iOS app v20.03.20. Should I wait for disclosure until the iOS app is updated?
